translations.convenience sample: sampling the accessible, ignoring the marginalized
translations.sampling bias: who gets a voice in the data
translations.common origin: all coming from the same place (not truly independent)
translations.dependent sources: circular sourcing (everyone quoting the same starting point)
translations.evidential strength: how well-proven is this? (strength of evidence)
translations.factual claim: provable claim (can be confirmed or disproven)
translations.interpretive claim: reading of the situation (interpretation, not just fact)
translations.secondary sources: reporting on the original (not direct witnesses)
translations.source contradiction: whose story is right? (sources contradicting each other)
translations.source independence: separate voices (not just echoing the same origin)
translations.source triangulation: who else confirms this? (backing up claims with multiple voices)
translations.source vulnerability: how shaky is this? (risk of being wrong or misled)
translations.triangulation level: how solid is this? (number of independent sources confirming)
translations.claim strength: can we rely on this (is the claim strong enough to act on)
translations.contested statistics: whose numbers count (competing versions of reality)
translations.correlation: how things are linked (patterns we can organize around)
translations.data patterns: evidence of systemic issues (patterns that prove injustice)
translations.data recency: are these today's numbers (or outdated information)
translations.methodology transparency: opening the black box (making their process visible)
translations.ratio: the inequality measure (how resources are divided)
translations.sample size adequacy: who got left out (was the study big enough and inclusive)
translations.statistical evidence: proof by numbers (what the data actually shows)
translations.Cohen's d: how big the gap is (standard measurement)
translations.Type I error: thinking you found something when you didn't
translations.analytical flexibility: how many options they had to get the answer they wanted
translations.p-value: shows if something's really happening or just luck
translations.post-hoc hypothesis: claiming you predicted what you only found by accident
translations.practical significance: makes a difference in people's lives
translations.variance explained: how much of the story this factor tells
translations.baseline comparison: the before picture they won't show
translations.excluded data: the full story they won't show you
translations.omission confidence: whether this is on purpose or accident
translations.scope limitation: why they only show part of the picture
translations.argumentative structure: how they try to convince you
translations.coherence: how well the pieces fit together
translations.convergent argument: building the case from multiple angles
translations.hierarchy: what they put first and what they bury
translations.inverted pyramid: putting the main point up front
translations.narrative arc: how the story moves from start to finish
translations.narrative pattern: the way they frame the journey
translations.organizational pattern: the order they put things in
translations.problem-solution pattern: here's what's wrong and here's the fix
translations.rhetorical structure: how they're trying to move you
translations.tree structure: one big point backed by many smaller ones
translations.boundary permeability: barriers they put up (who can cross)
translations.conceptual boundary: whose concerns count as real issues
translations.framing effect: how they tell the story to limit our options
translations.responsibility dispute: who's dodging their duty to act
translations.stakeholder boundary: whose voices are heard vs. silenced
translations.system boundary: who's inside and who's left out
translations.activity cluster: coordinated burst (everyone moving at the same time)
translations.anachronism: proof they're lying about when (timeline doesn't work)
translations.causal sequence: how it really happened (what led to what)
translations.corroboration status: who confirms this (whether independent sources agree)
translations.missing actor: who they erased (people removed from the timeline)
translations.temporal discontinuity: holes in the story (time periods they're hiding)
translations.timeline anomaly: something's off about when this happened
translations.timeline manipulation: covering their tracks (hiding what really happened)
translations.timestamp precision: whether they're vague about when (hiding behind fuzzy dates)
translations.bottom-up causation: how collective action forces system change
translations.meso-patterns: how the movement is growing or changing
translations.path dependencies: how history shapes what's possible now
translations.ruptures: when the old order breaks down
translations.scale interactions: connecting daily struggles to long-term change
translations.structural changes: rewriting the rules of the game
translations.time lags: when the seeds we plant will grow
translations.top-down causation: how the system controls our options
translations.trajectories: whether we're winning or losing ground
translations.turning points: victories or defeats that changed everything
translations.assumptions masquerading as knowledge: what they want us to believe without proof
translations.causal gap: missing the connection between cause and effect
translations.comparative gap: missing the contrast with how others are treated
translations.epistemic confidence: what we can actually count on knowing
translations.epistemological framework: how we organize what's known and unknown
translations.known unknowns: what we know we need to find out
translations.unasked questions: the questions that would expose the truth
translations.asset specificity: economic hostage situation (when you're stuck with one partner)
translations.bargaining costs: negotiation tax (what you pay to fight for fair terms)
translations.enforcement costs: making them pay (cost of getting justice for broken promises)
translations.governance structure: who's in charge (how power is organized)
translations.hold-up risk: the trap (invest first, get squeezed later)
translations.incomplete contracts: contract holes (missing protections in the deal)
translations.make-or-buy decision: independence vs. dependency (produce ourselves or buy from them)
translations.monitoring costs: accountability costs (what it takes to keep them honest)
translations.search costs: finding costs (what it takes to locate options)
translations.transaction costs: the hassle tax (extra costs beyond the price)
translations.critic's own failings: going after who said it instead of what was said
translations.deflection: avoiding accountability by changing the subject
translations.deflection target: where they're trying to shift blame
translations.false equivalence: comparing apples to oranges to avoid accountability
translations.implicit argument: what they're really trying to say
translations.original criticism: what they're being held accountable for
translations.substance avoidance: not dealing with the actual problem
translations.binary framing: acting like it's black and white when it's not
translations.causal from correlation: mixing up 'happens together' with 'makes it happen'
translations.certainty gap: the bluff (the difference between their confidence and their proof)
translations.complexity reduction: hiding the complications (acting like it's easy when it's messy)
translations.epistemic overreach: stretching the truth (going way past the evidence)
translations.expert disagreement: they're claiming it's settled when it's not
translations.limited sample generalization: taking one story and claiming it's everyone's story
translations.rhetorical certainty: talking like they're sure to make you believe them
translations.temporal projection: claiming they know what's coming (when nobody does)
translations.unearned certainty: fake confidence (pretending to know more than they do)
translations.universal quantifier: blanket statement (claiming it's true for everyone everywhere)
translations.warranted certainty: how sure they should really be
translations.balancing loops: stabilizing forces (what keeps things from changing)
translations.causal chains: impact chains (how effects connect and build)
translations.intervention: our move (the change we're pushing for)
translations.explicit value: what they say matters to them
translations.terminal value: the goal itself (not just a means)
translations.virtue ethics: building the right kind of people and communities
translations.breakthrough: when we break free of constraints
translations.saturation: hitting the wall (when we reach the limits)
translations.second derivative: whether the pace itself is changing
translations.citation inheritance: who you're in bed with when you quote them
translations.same word different concept: when people aren't actually talking about the same thing
translations.defeasibility: where they can be proven wrong

vocabulary.guidance_intro: NO JARGON. Every word must be accessible to everyone. Technical terms become weapons, tools, and calls to action.
vocabulary.guidance_outro: Could this be read aloud at a meeting and understood by everyone? If not, simplify it.
